awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Transitional Justice and State Intervention in Kinship
awd_abstract_narration:
The relationship between governments and families has long been complex. There is significant variation across contexts in the extent to which and in what ways states govern what constitutes a family and the limits imposed on family activities. This doctoral dissertation research project leverages transitional justice as a way of querying how families respond to changes in governmental policies regulating their structures and functions. It complements research that attempts to understand why governments regulate kinship by focusing instead on how families respond to governmental interventions and policies. Specifically, this research contributes to social scientific theories that relate kinship to the state by focusing on the survivor families’ experiences of transitional justice procedures. In addition to supporting the training of a graduate student, the findings of this research are disseminated broadly to academic, non-academic, and stakeholder audiences.

Transitional justice offers an opportunity to understand how state adjudication of past familial grievances impacts family relationships and activities. In this context, this doctoral dissertation research poses the following questions: 1) How do transitional justice courts decide which families' grievances are merited and what evidence do they muster to support decisions? 2) How are family relationships and activities affected by government decisions regarding claims of familial grievances? To answer these questions, the investigators conduct a multi-sited ethnographic study involving semi-structured interviews, participant observation, and archival analysis. In so doing, this doctoral research contributes to social science studies on the relationships between states and families by providing more nuanced theory via interrogation of these relationships in contexts marked by violence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This twelve-month ethnographic research was undertaken in South Korea (Jeju and Seoul) and Japan (Osaka) to examine whether the bureaucratic technologies of state administration deployed in the institutional apparatus of victimhood have the effect of reanimating state surveillance of kinship. For the primary data collection, this research employed archival research, introductory and semi-structured interviews, and participant observation, through repeated visits over time with interlocutors who have suffered the deaths of intimate kin during the violence of Jeju 4.3. The research method privileged close documentation of how people navigated the state decision on their victimhood in the kin network and how they negotiated with one another over kinship obligations to the dead while managing familial tensions among the living kin.

 

Through this approach, this research explored:

  1. the bureaucratic procedures which are used to adjudicate cases that establish the legal status of victim and bereaved family members,
  2. the ways in which the descendants of the people killed in the massacres mobilize evidence and negotiate among dispersed kin about decisions to petition for victim status or to appeal when such status is denied,
  3. the ways in which ritual practices bear the imprint of the state’s decision to grant or deny victimhood.

 

This research builds upon the anthropological analysis of law, kinship, and ritual by challenging the distinction between the domains of jural politics and family. The outcome of this research suggests that ethnographic attention to how law reworks kin relations between the dead and the living is crucial to understanding the repercussions of mass atrocity. Anthropological literature on transitional justice has examined how truth commissions uphold nation-building through institutional apparatuses of testimony and how particular voices are constrained by state institutions. Yet, it often assumes a boundary between the legal tools used to sustain victimhood and the bureaucratic apparatus of the state’s governance. By recognizing the assumption, this research offered an empirical investigation to examine what happens when the state’s legal recognition fails. Drawing from the anthropological critique of humanitarian reason, in which legal acknowledgement of victimhood is established through the generation of evidence-based knowledge, this research attended to the imprints of the government’s techniques for surveilling its people via the family registration system in South Korea. It examined how the South Korean government, through the Jeju 4.3 Incident Special Act, recasts the liminal status of the dead as honorable ancestors to demonstrate the ways in which the conjunction of law and rituals is marked by kinship and how the bureaucratic procedures of claims-making carry residues of violence that evoke emotions across kin relations. Furthermore, it examined how the legal claims of victimhood take shape within a transnational space and how the perspective of the island casts an entirely different light on the construction of national memory politics spatially bound to the peninsula. This research contributes to an academic understanding of the state intervention in the familial space that legitimates the legal conditions of “victims” and “bereaved.”

 

While most of the critical discussions of reparative justice worldwide have so far focused on expanding the benefits of official victims and bereaved rather than the exclusions of their legal status, this research has broader societal impacts. This research generated records that detail (a) how bureaucratic criteria accorded the denial of victimhood status, (b) how people mobilized evidence and negotiated among dispersed kin to appeal in cases in which such status was denied, and (c) how ritual practices adapted to state decisions of victimhood. This data is useful in critically assessing policies pertaining to the investigation of the state’s past wrongdoings. Thus, this academic work can provide an entry point for intervening in discussions between governments and civil societies in enacting or revising laws relating to the redress of state atrocities.
